text: hi there our tests and departmental
production systems are now running on
the AWS cloud and we turn them on and
off depending on usage requirements
considering the success we had with
deploying Microsoft SharePoint on AWS
I'm thinking about using it for the new
corporate farm is it designed to handle
our volumes and meet the high
reliability SLA the business requires
for this deployment yes of course you
already know that the deployment on the
AWS cloud can be scaled up and down as
in when required for even greater
flexibility and optimization you can
deploy a streamlined topology so that
different servers can be scaled
separately our present architecture uses
public and private subnets for security
can we replicate that in AWS you can
create a public facing subnet to handle
incoming traffic from an Internet
gateway and deploy an at instance for
Windows Update the SharePoint servers
databases and Active Directory servers
can be provisioned in a private subnet
with no internet access these SharePoint
deployments are critical to the business
does the AWS cloud let me provide high
availability absolutely just place the
servers in at least two availability
zones in case of an availability zone
outage this architecture allows access
to the resources that may have failed
over to the other availability zone what
about balancing the need for remote
administration with the need for
security no problem you can deploy rd
gateways into the public subnets for
remote administration and restrict
access to your specified IP address
range then use security groups to
restrict access to the private subnet to
only the HTTP and rdp protocols from the
public subnet how do i integrate this
with our Active Directory
you can use a hybrid architecture that
extends your private on-premises network
to AWS so that the resources in the AWS
cloud use your existing ad
infrastructure you can even deploy
domain controllers for your existing ad
forest to the AWS cloud this ensures
that the SharePoint servers deployed in
AWS remain functional and available in
the event of an on-premises outage you
can also use the AWS directory service
ad connector to proxy ad requests from
the cloud to your on-premises ad domain
what about the database tier for small
or medium sized environments you might
want to place all of your databases on a
single server Amazon machine images for
sequel server express sequel server web
edition and sequel server standard
edition are available for launch on AWS
or you can use microsoft license
mobility through Software Assurance to
bring your own licenses into the AWS
cloud what if I need sequel server
enterprise for high availability
requirements you can deploy sequel
server always on availability groups in
AWS so that you can spread your
databases across a sequel server cluster
spanning two availability zones do I
have to build my SharePoint farms piece
by piece or is there an easier way to
build them AWS provides a quick start
reference guide and an AWS
CloudFormation template free of charge
so who's using the AWS cloud for
sharepoint server deployments customers
find it especially beneficial where the
workload varies because you can quickly
scale up or down as and when required
companies are also using AWS deployments
as standby for disaster recovery if the
primary fails the AWS deployment can be
spun up quickly to take over the
workload without the need for dedicated
hardware how much does it cost AWS
provides a cost estimator calculator
where you can plug in the number and
type of Amazon ec2 instances you plan to
deploy as usual you only pay for what
you use there are no minimum fees and no
up from commitments
please complete the hands-on lab for
this video at run quick labs com this
lab should take you approximately two
hours to complete
